hints.content: Start by understanding the relationship between length (L), width (W), and area. The area of a rectangle is calculated as L * W. So, if you know the area, you can express W as area / L.
Remember that the problem states L must be greater than or equal to W. This means you need to find pairs (L, W) where L >= W while ensuring L * W equals the given area.

Consider the constraints on L and W. Since L and W must be integers, you will need to check integer values for L starting from the square root of the area down to 1. Why start from the square root? Because this will help minimize the difference between L and W.
The smallest difference between L and W occurs when both are as close as possible to the square root of the area. Calculate the integer square root of the area and use it as a starting point for L.
When iterating down from the integer square root, check if the area is divisible by the current L. If it is, calculate W as area / L. This ensures that both L and W are integers.
As you find valid pairs (L, W), keep track of the pair that has the smallest difference |L - W|. This will help you meet the requirement of minimizing the difference.
Pay attention to the edge case where the area is 1. What will be the values of L and W in this case? Think about how the constraints apply here.
Make sure to return the result in the format specified: an array [L, W]. Double-check that L is always the first element and W is the second element.

If you find multiple pairs with the same difference, remember that you only need to return the first one you find that meets the conditions. This is because L should always be greater than or equal to W.

Now, put together your logic into a loop that starts from the integer square root of the area and goes downwards, checking divisibility, calculating W, and comparing differences. You are very close to the final solution!

questionNotes: L must be greater than or equal to W (L >= W).
If multiple pairs have the same difference, return the first valid pair found.
